title: Protections against porting scams to be forced on all telcos by April
text:
Mr Fletcher has issued a formal direction to the Australian Communications and Media Authority to make the new rules compulsory, as the government's scam-technology project continues to work on solutions to fight the problem that has emerged in phone and internet usage.

A report from ACMA on the project's progress is expected next month.

"As long as there are any companies which don't do this, there continues to be a vulnerability and so that's why the Morrison government is acting to require every mobile company to introduce two-factor authentication," Mr Fletcher said.

"The stakes are pretty high. Several thousand people have fallen victim to identity theft using fraudulent porting of a mobile number and on average the amount that has been lost is over $10,000 – as well as all the time and inconvenience that is involved in re-establishing control of what is rightfully your mobile number."

The Australian Taxation Office is among the government agencies working to fight the phone scams, which include the sophisticated "spoofing" of ATO phone numbers, designed to give taxpayers the impression that demands for urgent repayment of debt or investigations are legitimate.

The ATO has received more than 114,000 reports of scams and estimates the annual losses for victims at $3 million.

Advertisement

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission recently said losses reported to the Scamwatch service were likely to reach $532 million in 2019.

Experts believe that about one in three victims of a porting scam suffers, on average, a financial loss of $11,368.

Mr Fletcher said he would look at further options to limit the success of phone-based scams in the coming months.

"We are also, through the scam-technology project, examining other issues including calls made to Australians purporting to be from the Australian Taxation Office or other well-known and trusted organisations," he said.

"What I say to Australians is if you have any doubt at all about who is calling you, put the phone down and then if you think it's the Australian Taxation Office, call back using one of their published numbers.

"That's an important step you can take to protect yourself."
description: About a million Australian phone customers will have extra protection against porting scams as the government moves to new industry-wide standards.
